{{distinguish|Russell Peterson|Peter Russell (disambiguation){{!}}Peter Russell}} {{infobox comedian | name = Russell Peters | image = RussellPeters08TIFF.jpg | caption = Peters in 2008 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Russell Dominic Peters | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1970|9|29}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[film]], [[radio]], [[book]]s | genre = [[Satire]], [[observational comedy]], [[improvisational theatre|improvisational comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[insult comedy]] | active = 1989–present | subject = [[Racism]], [[race relations]], [[stereotype]]s, [[multiculturalism]], [[Culture of India|Indian culture]], [[Culture of Asia|Asian culture]] | influences = [[George Carlin]],{{cite web |author=Alan Cho, Gauntlet Entertainment |url=http://gauntlet.ucalgary.ca/a/story/9549 |title=Gauntlet Entertainment — Comedy Preview: Russell Peters won't a hurt you real bad! - 2005-11-24 |publisher=Gauntlet.ucalgary.ca |date=2005-11-24 |accessdate=2009-07-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604125849/http://gauntlet.ucalgary.ca/a/story/9549 |archivedate=2009-06-04 |df= }} [[Steve Martin]], [[Cheech & Chong]],{{cite web|title=Said with a Punch|work=The Official Website of Russell Peters|url=http://www.russellpeters.com/Press/Said-with-a-Punch_1|date=2006-12-01|accessdate=2012-11-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119232215/http://www.russellpeters.com/Press/Said-with-a-Punch_1|archive-date=2012-11-19|dead-url=yes|df=}}
[[Don Rickles]], [[Eddie Murphy]] | signature = Russell Peters Autograph.svg | website = [http://www.RussellPeters.com/ RussellPeters.com] | spouse = Monica Diaz (2010–2012; divorced; 1 child) }} '''Russell Dominic Peters''' (born September 29, 1970){{cite web|title=Russell Peters biography|newspaper=[[Tribute (magazine)|Tribute]]|access-date=17 May 2015|url=http://www.tribute.ca/people/russell-peters/37405/}} is a Canadian [[stand-up comedian]] and [[actor]] of [[Indian people|Indian]] descent.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/vannale/2014/02/14/why-russell-peters-is-notoriously-unknown/#751e4c063f22|title=Why Russell Peters Is Notoriously Unknown|first=Vanna|last=Le|publisher=[[Forbes]]|date=February 14, 2014}} He began performing in [[Toronto]] in 1989 and won a [[Gemini Award]] in 2008. In 2013, he was number three on ''[[Forbes]]''{{'}} list of the world's highest-paid comedians, and became the first comedian to get a [[Netflix]] stand-up special.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/10/16/living/identity-comedy-russell-peters-netflix/index.html|title=The famous comedian most Americans don't know|date=16 October 2013|publisher=edition.cnn.com}} He also won the [[Peabody Award]] and the [[International Emmy Award for Best Arts Programming]] for producing ''[[Hip-Hop Evolution]]'' (2016). He currently lives in [[Los Angeles]].{{cite news| last= Hough| first= Robert| title= Lighten Up| url= http://www.torontolife.com/features/lighten-up-russell-peters/| accessdate= 29 January 2012| newspaper= Toronto Life| date= September 2009| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090926184248/http://www.torontolife.com/features/lighten-up-russell-peters/| archive-date= 26 September 2009| dead-url= yes| df= dmy-all}} ==Early life== Peters was born in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] to Eric and Maureen Peters. When he was four, the family moved to the suburb of [[Brampton]]. His older brother Clayton now serves as his manager.[https://www.thestar.com/life/2012/12/14/comedian_russell_peters_talks_about_his_manager_and_big_brother_clayton.html Comedian Russell Peters talks about his manager and big brother, Clayton.] ''Toronto Star''. Accessed on March 25, 2013. Peters was raised [[Catholic]] and is of [[Anglo-Indian]] descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.russellpeters.com/FAQ.aspx |title=Archive from The Official Website of Russell Peters |publisher=Russellpeters.com |date=2013-04-27 |accessdate=2016-11-01 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150320090244/http://www.russellpeters.com/FAQ.aspx |archivedate=2015-03-20 |df= }} His late father was born in [[Mumbai]], [[Maharashtra]], India and worked in Toronto as a federal meat inspector; Peters regularly features stories about him in his comedy work. Peters attended [[Chinguacousy Secondary School]] for grades 9–10, and [[Judith Nyman Secondary School|North Peel Secondary School]] in [[Bramalea, Ontario|Bramalea]] for grades 11–12.{{cite web|author=Post Reply |url=http://www.mahalo.com/russell-peters |title=Russell Peters |publisher=Mahalo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-11}}{{cite web |author=Jonathan Morvay |url=http://punchlinemagazine.com/blog/2010/04/russell-peters-creates-20000-college-scholarship |title=Punchline Magazine Blog: " Russell Peters creates $20,000 college scholarship — Comedy Blog, Comedy News, and all things in Stand Up Comedy |publisher=Punchlinemagazine.com |date=2010-04-30 |accessdate=2011-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110704023926/http://punchlinemagazine.com/blog/2010/04/russell-peters-creates-20000-college-scholarship |archivedate=2011-07-04 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/294038 |title= Comedian Russell Peters awards scholarship to Randy Adams |publisher=Digitaljournal.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-11}} In school, he was regularly bullied [[racism|because of his ethnicity]]. He eventually learned [[boxing]], which helped him resist the bullying.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/books-and-media/russell-peters-call-him-grateful/article1321408/ "Call him grateful"], ''The Globe and Mail''. Accessed on November 6, 2012. Peters also became a [[hip hop music|hip hop]] "junkie" in his youth. By the 1990s, he was a well-connected [[disc jockey]] in the Toronto scene.[http://www.russellpeters.com/faq.aspx FAQ], RussellPeters.com. Accessed on November 6, 2012[https://web.archive.org/web/20120629225905/http://www.djmag.ca/2012/06/27/russell-peteres-comedian-dj-anti-fist-pumper/ "RUSSELL PETERS: COMEDIAN, DJ, ANTI-FIST PUMPER"], ''DJ Mag'', Accessed on November 6, 2012 ==Career== Peters began performing in Toronto in 1989. He has since gone on to perform in several countries worldwide.{{cite web|last=Mohr|first=Jay|title=Mohr Stories 87: Russell Peters|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/mohr-stories-fakemustache.com/id448795390|work=Mohr Stories|publisher=Fake Mustache Studios|accessdate=8 September 2012}} In 1992, Peters met American comedian [[George Carlin]], one of his biggest influences, who advised him to get on stage whenever and wherever possible. Peters said he "took that advice to heart, and I think that's the reason I am where I am now."[http://www.russellpeters.com/Press/Russell-Peters---10-Comics-to-Watch_4 Russell Peters - 10 Comics to Watch] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403034823/http://russellpeters.com/Press/Russell-Peters---10-Comics-to-Watch_4 |date=2013-04-03 }} RussellPeters.com. Accessed on March 25, 2013. In 2007, 15 years later, he hosted one of Carlin's last shows before Carlin's death the following year. Peters credits his 2004 performance on the Canadian TV comedy show ''[[Comedy Now!]]'', which was uploaded onto [[YouTube]] and became [[viral video|viral]], as the turning point in his career. While the initial video upload featured his entire 45-minute performance, YouTube users subsequently uploaded segments of the performance in which Peters focused on individual cultural groups. According to Peters, those segments made their way to the "targeted" cultural groups and were well received by them. The video and its viral nature was referred to by Peters on his performance, ''Outsourced''; when the audience cheered when he referred to earlier jokes, he exclaimed, "Look at you, you filthy downloaders!"{{cite web|title=Russell Peters: Outsourced Aired on COMEDYP — Ark TV Transcript|url=http://tv.ark.com/transcript/russell_peters__outsourced/6732/COMEDYP/Saturday_December_19_2009/140807/|website=tv.ark.com|accessdate=1 September 2015|ref=Russell Peters: Outsourced Aired on COMEDYP — Ark TV Transcript|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111234057/http://tv.ark.com/transcript/russell_peters__outsourced/6732/COMEDYP/Saturday_December_19_2009/140807/|archive-date=11 January 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} In 2017, Peters made an appearance on ''[[Top Gear America]]'' in the third episode of Season 1 as one of the guests.https://www.autoblog.com/2017/08/10/top-gear-america-episode-three-exclusive-preview-magnus-walker/?guccounter=1 ===Notable performances=== In 2007, Peters was the first comedian to sell out Toronto's [[Air Canada Centre]], selling more than 16,000 tickets in two days for the single show. He ended up selling more than 30,000 tickets nationally over the two-day sales period. He broke a UK comedy sales record at London's [[O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] when he sold over 16,000 tickets to his show in 2009.{{cite web|title=The Official Russell Peters Website, Hi-lites|url=http://www.russellpeters.com/biography.aspx|publisher=russellpeters.com|date=|accessdate=2011-08-07|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826115547/http://russellpeters.com/Biography.aspx|archivedate=2011-08-26|df=}} His show in [[Sydney]] on 15 May 2010 had an audience of 13,880, making it the largest stand-up comedy show ever in Australia.{{cite news|title=World laughs with you|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/comedy/world-laughs-with-you-20100513-v1ce.html|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=13 May 2010}} Peters's performances on May 5–6, 2012 in Singapore also set attendance records for a single stand-up comedian at the Singapore Indoor Stadium.{{cite web|title=Have a hearty laugh|url=http://www.ttgmice.com/magazine/?term_id&issues=231&ID=33277|publisher=TTGmice|accessdate=16 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225011/http://www.ttgmice.com/magazine/?term_id&issues=231&ID=33277|archivedate=2 December 2013|df=}} Peters hosted the [[Canada Day]] Comedy Festival 2006, and participated in a [[USO tour]] of Iraq, Afghanistan, Germany, Africa and Greenland in November 2007 with [[Wilmer Valderrama]] and [[Mayra Veronica]].{{cite news| url=http://www.defenselink.mil/PhotoEssays/PhotoEssaySS.aspx?ID=522| title=USO visits Bagram| publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]]| date=November 21, 2007| accessdate=2008-01-24}} He also produced and starred in the [[radio comedy|radio]] [[situation comedy]] series ''[[Monsoon House]]'' on [[CBC Radio One]]. Peters was the host of the televised [[Juno Awards of 2008|2008 Juno Awards]] ceremonies in [[Calgary]] on April 6, 2008,{{cite web |url = http://www.junoawards.ca/PDF/20080205_f.pdf |format = PDF |title = Russell Peters to Host The 2008 Juno Awards, April 6 on CTV |accessdate = 2008-02-05 |date = February 5, 2008 |publisher = [[Canadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences|CARAS]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080216000747/http://www.junoawards.ca/PDF/20080205_f.pdf |archivedate = 2008-02-16 |deadurl = yes |df = }} for which he won a Gemini Award for "Best Performance or Host in a Variety Program or Series".[http://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/self-proclaimed-mainstream-nickelback-reigns-at-junos-1.832409 "Self-proclaimed 'mainstream' Nickelback reigns at Junos"]. ''CBC Arts'', Mar 29, 2009 The show received the second-highest ratings of any Juno Awards broadcast. Following the show's success, Peters accepted an invitation to host the [[Juno Awards]] for a second consecutive year; the [[Juno Awards of 2009|2009 Juno Awards]] took place in [[Vancouver]] on March 29, 2009. On September 28, 2013, Peters was awarded the 2013 Trailblazer award by the Association of South Asians in Media, Marketing and Entertainment (SAMMA) for his contributions to the world of comedy. He is among the first South Asians to achieve international success in the field. ===DVDs and book=== Peters released his debut comedy album, ''[[Outsourced (album)|Outsourced]]'', of his performance aired on [[Comedy Central]] on August 26, 2006. The DVD version is uncensored; it has sold more than 100,000 copies, and remained on the National DVD Chart over one and a half years after its release. Peters released a second DVD/CD combo, ''[[Red, White and Brown]]'', in Canada in 2008, and in the U.S. in early 2009. It was recorded on February 2, 2008, at the WAMU Theatre in [[Madison Square Garden]] in New York City. It was self-produced and financed by Peters and his brother Clayton. In May 2011, Peters released ''The Green Card Tour: Live from the O2 Arena'', a live performance recorded in front of a total audience of 30,000, over two nights at [[The O2 (London)|O2 Arena]] in [[London]], England.{{cite news|title=Russell Peters releases third DVD, panic ensues|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/article/999839--russell-peters-releases-third-dvd-panic-ensues?bn=1|publisher=thestar.com|accessdate=29 January 2012|location=Toronto|first=Lorianna|last=De Giorgio|date=31 May 2011}} The show was directed by Dave Higby, who produced ''Outsourced''. On October 26, 2010, Peters published his autobiography, ''Call Me Russell'', co-written with his brother Clayton and Dannis Koromilas. ===Earnings=== According to ''[[Forbes]]'', Peters earned an estimated $15 million between June 2009 and June 2010, continuing his run as one of the highest-paid comedians, after earning an estimated $5 million the prior year. ''Forbes'' ranked him as the third-highest-paid comedian.{{cite news|author=Lacey Rose |url=https://www.forbes.com/2010/09/07/handler-dunham-cook-fator-business-entertainment-top-earning-comedians_slide_8.html |title=In Pictures: The 10 Top Earning Comedians - 7) Russell Peters |publisher=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-17 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120731061447/http://www.forbes.com/2010/09/07/handler-dunham-cook-fator-business-entertainment-top-earning-comedians_slide_8.html |archivedate=2012-07-31 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|author=Lacey Rose |url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/07/13/top-earning-comedians-business-entertainment-top-earning-comedians_slide_11.html |title=In Pictures: The 10 Top Earning Comedians - 9) Russell Peters, (tie) |publisher=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-06 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130104103600/http://www.forbes.com/2009/07/13/top-earning-comedians-business-entertainment-top-earning-comedians_slide_11.html |archivedate=2013-01-04 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2013, he earned $21 million, according to ''Forbes''{{'}} estimate.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/fjik45eee/no-3-russell-peters/|title=No. 3: Russell Peters - In Photos: The Top-Earning Comedians of 2013|last=Feeney|first=Nolan|website=Forbes|access-date=2016-04-21}} ==Comedic style== Peters's stand-up performances feature [[observational comedy]], using humour to highlight racial, ethnic, class and cultural stereotypes. He often refers to his own experiences growing up in an Anglo-Indian family, and impersonates the accents of various ethnic groups to poke fun at them. As he told an audience in San Francisco, "I don't make the stereotypes, I just see them."{{cite news|last=Piccalo|first=Gina|title=No joke — Russell Peters is a famous comedian|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/apr/16/entertainment/la-et--russell-peters-20100416|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=LA Times|date=16 April 2010}} In a 2006 interview with ''[[The National (CBC)|The National]],'' Peters observed that he did not intend to put down or offend different races and cultures, but tried to "raise them up through humour".Clifton Joseph, "Russell Peters Interview on CBC The National, May 30th 2006" Peters is widely known for his punchline, "Somebody gonna get a hurt real bad." It ends a joke he tells about his childhood with a traditional Indian father, who used corporal punishment on his sons. Another punchline he uses is "Be a man! Do the right thing!", which relates to a story of a Chinese man trying to get him to pay more for an item at a shop.{{cite news|last=Nguyen|first=An|title=Defying Stereotypes and Breaking All Laws of Decency, Russell Peters Lets It All Hang Out|url=http://culturemagazine.ca/culture/defying_stereotypes_and_breaking_all_laws_of_decency_russell_peters_lets_it_all_hang_out.html|accessdate=29 January 2012|newspaper=(Cult)ure magazine|date=19 May 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111115223351/http://culturemagazine.ca/culture/defying_stereotypes_and_breaking_all_laws_of_decency_russell_peters_lets_it_all_hang_out.html|archivedate=15 November 2011|df=}} When interviewer [[Larry King]] asked Peters, "Is there such a thing as too taboo?", Peters replied, "I don't talk about religion because I think people are a little weird about religion, especially nowadays, and I'm more of a science guy than I am a beliefs guy. I'm more into facts than I am into beliefs."''Larry King Now'', Ora TV https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kunZO5i2JnA (1:30){{cite web|url=http://www.ora.tv/larrykingnow/2014/8/6/lknpetersrussell004-0_5yhqhlfpfu7y|title=Russell Peters: I Don’t Talk About Religion|publisher=}} In an interview with ''Al Jazeera'', Peters said he "refuses" to talk about religion.''Al Jazeera'' English: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hKXxiccJx9c (3:30){{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/sep/17/russell-peters-avoids-religion-in-his-comedy-act/|title=Russell Peters avoids religion in his comedy act|first=The Washington Times|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|publisher=}} ==Personal life== [[File:Ruzanna Khetchian and Russell Peters - Hip Hop Evolution.jpg|thumb|right|Peters with Khetchian]] Peters dated [[Sunny Leone]], a former [[pornographic actress|porn star]], who has been a [[Bollywood]] actress since 2008.{{cite news|last=Goyal|first=Samarth|title=Sunny Leone is a real sweetheart: Russell Peters|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/tabloid/sunny-leone-is-a-real-sweetheart-russell-peters/article1-1140756.aspx|accessdate=29 October 2013|newspaper=Hindustan Times|date=September 2013}} He was in a relationship with her before she began shooting boy-girl scenes in 2007, which led to their breakup.{{cite web |title=Comedian Russell Peters Goes Off on Trevor Noah + Names His Top 5 Comedians |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aGXWYomn_6s |website=[[YouTube]] |publisher=[[Sway Calloway|Sway's Universe]] |accessdate=July 27, 2018 |date=June 28, 2018 |minutes=12}} He proposed to girlfriend Monica Diaz on July 10, 2010 at the [[Los Angeles International Airport]] and announced their engagement via [[Twitter]]. The couple married on August 20, 2010 at [[A Little White Wedding Chapel]] in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. The wedding was attended by about 20 guests, including an [[Elvis impersonator]]. Soon after, Peters told ''[[The Canadian Press]]'' that Diaz was pregnant, saying, "Did I get married because she was knocked up? I would say that expedited it."{{cite web|url=http://www.680news.com/entertainment/article/120247--russell-peters-and-wife-monica-diaz-expecting-baby-girl-in-february|title=Russell Peters and wife, Monica Diaz, expecting baby girl in February|publisher=[[680 News]]|date=October 26, 2010|access-date=June 8, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120707091918/http://www.680news.com/entertainment/article/120247--russell-peters-and-wife-monica-diaz-expecting-baby-girl-in-february|archive-date=July 7, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Their daughter Crystianna Marie Peters was born two months early on December 14, 2010.{{cite web| url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Entertainment/20110531/russell-peters-fatherhood-film-dvd-release-110531/|title=Russell Peters eases into fatherhood and film| publisher=[[CTV News]]|date=May 31, 2011}} In a March 2012 interview, Peters revealed that he and Diaz were divorcing.{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/arts-entertainment/music/russell-peters-bring-on-the-funny-1.996349|title=Russell Peters: Bring on the Funny|publisher=[[Gulf News]]| date= March 19, 2012}}{{cite web| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/theatre-and-performance/a-busy-russell-peters-divorcing-renovating-touring-world/article4267635/|title=A busy Russell Peters divorcing, renovating, touring world| work= [[The Globe and Mail]]|date=June 15, 2012}} {{As of|October 2016}}, he was engaged to Ruzanna Khetchian.[http://z1035.com/russell-peters-is-engaged/ "Russell Peters Is Engaged!"]. ''Z1035 Radio''. October 4, 2016 Peters lives in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] and owns two homes there. He also owns homes in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] and [[Vaughan]], [[Ontario]]. In 2010 Peters established the Russell Peters North Peel Scholarship, an award worth up to $21,000 and intended to finance up to three years of college. It will be awarded annually to a student from [[Judith Nyman Secondary School]] (formerly North Peel) with a strong academic record and the intention of attending college.{{cite web |first= Jonathan |last= Morvay |url= http://punchlinemagazine.com/blog/2010/04/russell-peters-creates-20000-college-scholarship |title= Russell Peters creates $20,000 college scholarship |publisher= Punchlinemagazine.com |date= 2010-04-30 |accessdate= 2011-03-11 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110704023926/http://punchlinemagazine.com/blog/2010/04/russell-peters-creates-20000-college-scholarship |archivedate= 2011-07-04 |df= }} ==Filmography== Russell Peters has appeared in many films. He acted in the Punjabi-Canadian ''[[Breakaway (2011 film)|Breakaway]]'' (2011), alongside [[Camilla Belle]], [[Anupam Kher]], and [[Vinay Virmani]]. That year he also acted in [[Duncan Jones]]'s ''[[Source Code]]'' (2011) as Max, an amateur comedian with a bad attitude; and as Pervius in ''[[National Lampoon's 301: The Legend of Awesomest Maximus]]'' (2011).{{cite web|last=Compolongo|first=Gabrielle|title=EXCLUSIVE: Russell Peters Talks Source Code, Working with Jake Gyllenhaal|url=http://www.moviefanatic.com/2011/03/exclusive-russell-peters-talks-source-code-working-with-jake-gyl/|publisher=Movie Fanatic|accessdate=29 January 2012}} He appeared in ''[[Senior Skip Day]]'' (2008), which starred [[Larry Miller (entertainer)|Larry Miller]], [[Tara Reid]], and Gary Lundy. That year he was also in ''[[The Take (2008 film)|The Take]]'' (2008) as Dr. Sharma. Earlier he had cameo roles in ''Boozecan'' (1994) as Snake's Friend, ''Tiger Claws III'' (2000) as Detective Elliott, ''[[My Baby's Daddy]]'' (2004) as the obstetrician, and ''Quarter Life Crisis'' (2006) as Dilip Kumar. Peters has guest-starred on the TV series ''[[Mr. D]]'' as the school superintendent. In 2011, he starred in a Canadian TV Christmas special, ''A Russell Peters Christmas''. Guests included [[Michael Bublé]], [[Pamela Anderson]] and [[Jon Lovitz]].
